diagram.documentation: This functional tree represents the core operational structure of an autonomous orbital manufacturing system. It comprises eight primary functions: (1) Conduct Autonomous Orbital Manufacturing Operations, (2) Maintain Operational Availability of Orbital Platform, (3) Ensure Compliance with Regulatory and Safety Standards, (4) Manage Resources and Logistics for Orbital Manufacturing, (5) Fault Recovery and Remote Override, (6) Monitor and Analyze System Performance, (7) On-Orbit Assembly, Activation, and Upgrade, and (8) Manage Orbital Position and Attitude. These functions interact through a complex network of inputs and outputs, both external and internal, as illustrated in the accompanying N2 diagram. The system is designed to operate in microgravity conditions, handling various inputs such as raw materials, environmental data, and control commands, while producing outputs including manufactured products, system status reports, and operational metrics. This functional architecture enables the system to autonomously manage manufacturing processes, maintain platform integrity, ensure regulatory compliance, and adapt to the unique challenges of the space environment.

stringtaggedvalue.name:
descriptionArea = "

The Activity Decomposition Map allows rapid review, analysis and creation of relations among the Activities of the selected context.

To create Activity Decomposition Map:

  1. Drag an Activity from the Model Browser to the Activity Decomposition Map.
  2. Specify Scope.

Activity Decomposition Map can display the model structure in two different layouts: tree or radial. The relations represented on the map can be analyzed in one of the following ways:

- Dynamically - according to the applied filters: element type, dependencies criterion, depth, and scope.

- Statically - step-by-step expanding the branches of the structure. To represent the same element as a single node in the map, click the Options button on the toolbar and select the Show Single Node Per Element command.

Manipulations:

Create a relation map structure - drag an element from the Model Browser to the relation map.

Create new element of the same type - type element name and press Ctrl+Enter.

Restore manually suppressed / expanded branches and hidden elements and they position - click the Refresh button .

Expand / suppress branches - click / near the node.

Move the whole structure - click an empty place on the Relation Map and drag.

Move the selected no...

property.name: descriptionArea
property.String:
The Activity Decomposition Map allows rapid review, analysis and creation of relations among the Activities of the selected context.

 

 

To create Activity Decomposition Map:

  1. Drag an Activity from the Model Browser to the Activity Decomposition Map.
  2. Specify Scope.

Activity Decomposition Map can display the model structure in two different layouts: tree or radial. The relations represented on the map can be analyzed in one of the following ways:

 

 

- Dynamically - according to the applied filters: element type, dependencies criterion, depth, and scope.

- Statically - step-by-step expanding the branches of the structure. To represent the same element as a single node in the map, click the Options button on the toolbar and select the Show Single Node Per Element command.

 

 


Manipulations:

 

Create a relation map structure - drag an element from the Model Browser to the relation map.

Create new element of the same type - type element name and press Ctrl+Enter.

Restore manually suppressed / expanded branches and hidden elements and they position - click the Refresh button .

Expand / suppress branches - click  /  near the node.   

Move the whole structure - click an empty place on the Relation Map and drag.

Move the selected node - click the node and drag.

Zoom in hold down Ctrl while scrolling up.

Zoom out - hold down Ctrl while scrolling down.

Fit in window - press Ctrl+W.

Zoom 1:1 - press Ctrl+NumPad /.

Turn on the ability to change the context element with single click - click the Options button on the toolbar and then select the Make Element as Context on Selection command.

 

Filters:

Context - the core element of the structure.

Scope - fragment of the model (or the whole model) from which the relation map is built.

Depth - level of branches automatically expanded starting from the context element.

property.name: relationCriterion
